AAA: Security protocols for controlling access to computer systems.
ACL: A list of rules that specify which users or system processes are granted access to objects, as well as what operations are allowed on given objects.
AES-256: A variant of AES with a key length of 256 bits for enhanced security.
AH: A component of the IPsec protocol suite used to guarantee the authenticity and integrity of transmitted messages.
AI: The simulation of human intelligence processes by machines, especially computer systems.
AIS: The automated exchange of cyber threat indicators between organizations.
ALE: A calculation used to assess the expected financial loss from a security incident.
AP: A networking hardware device that allows a Wi-Fi device to connect to a wired network.
API: A set of rules that allows one software application to interact with another.
APT: A prolonged, targeted cyber attack in which an intruder gains access to a network and remains undetected for an extended period.
ARO: A metric used in risk assessment to estimate the frequency of a specific threat.
ARP: A protocol used to map an IP address to a physical machine address (MAC address) on a local network.
ASLR: A security feature that randomizes the memory locations used by system files and key program components.
ATT&CK: Adversarial Tactics, Techniques, and Common Knowledge
A knowledge base used to describe the actions and behaviors of cyber adversaries.
AUP: A set of rules governing the use of computer systems and networks.
AV: Software designed to detect and remove malicious software (malware) from a computer or network.
BASH: A command processor that typically runs in a text window where the user types commands that cause actions.
BCP: The process of developing systems of prevention and recovery to deal with potential threats to a company.
BGP: A standardized exterior gateway protocol used to exchange routing and reachability information between autonomous systems on the Internet.
BIA: An analysis to identify and evaluate the potential effects of disruptions to critical business operations.
BIOS: Firmware used to perform hardware initialization during the booting process.
BPA: An agreement between business partners defining their rights, responsibilities, and expectations.
BPDU: A frame sent out by a bridge in a computer network that contains information used to detect loops.
BYOD: A policy allowing employees to bring personally owned devices to their workplace.
CA: A trusted entity that issues digital certificates used in public key cryptography.
CAPTCHA: Completely Automated Public Turing Test to Tell Computers and Humans Apart
A challenge-response test used to determine whether the user is human or automated software.
CAR: A report documenting actions taken to correct identified issues or deficiencies.
CASB: A security policy enforcement point placed between cloud service consumers and cloud service providers.
CBC: A mode of operation for cryptographic block ciphers to provide confidentiality.
CCMP: A protocol used in Wi-Fi networks to provide data confidentiality and integrity.
CCTV: A system of video cameras used for surveillance purposes.
CERT: A team of information security experts responsible for protecting an organization from cybersecurity threats.
CFB: A mode of operation for a block cipher, working with arbitrary block sizes.
CHAP: A secure authentication protocol used to authenticate a user or network host to an authenticating entity.
CIA: The three core principles of information security.
CIO: A senior executive responsible for the information technology and computer systems of an enterprise.
CIRT: A group of professionals responsible for managing and responding to computer security incidents.
CMS: A software application used to create, edit, manage, and publish digital content.
COOP: A process that helps organizations prepare for and ensure the continuation of essential functions during and after a disaster.
COPE: A mobile device management strategy in which an organization provides and owns the devices used by employees.
CP: A process that helps organizations prepare for and respond to potential disruptions.
CRC: A method used to detect errors in data during transmission.
CRL: A list of digital certificates that have been revoked by the issuing certificate authority.
CSO: A senior executive responsible for the overall security posture of an organization.
CSP: A company that offers various IT services over the internet.
CSR: A message sent from an applicant to a certificate authority to apply for a digital identity certificate.
CSRF: An attack that tricks the victim into submitting a malicious request.
CSU: A device that connects a terminal to a digital circuit, such as a T1 or T3 line.
CTM: A mode of operation for cryptographic block ciphers.
CTO: A senior executive responsible for the technological direction of an organization.
CVE: A system for identifying and naming cybersecurity vulnerabilities.
CVSS: A framework for scoring the severity of software vulnerabilities.
CYOD: A policy allowing employees to choose from a list of approved devices for work purposes.
DAC: A security model where each subject has an associated set of permissions.
DBA: A person responsible for the design, implementation, and maintenance of an organization's databases.
DDoS: An attack in which multiple compromised computers are used to flood a target system with traffic.
DEP: A security feature that helps prevent damage from viruses and other security threats.
DES: A symmetric-key algorithm for the encryption of electronic data.
DHCP: A network management protocol used to dynamically assign IP addresses to devices on a network.
DHE: A variant of the Diffie-Hellman key exchange protocol that provides perfect forward secrecy.
DKIM: An email authentication method that allows the person receiving the email to check that it was actually sent by the domain it claims to be from.
DLL: A file containing code and data that can be used by multiple programs simultaneously.
DLP: A set of tools and processes used to ensure that sensitive data is not lost, misused, or accessed by unauthorized users.
DMARC: Domain Message Authentication Reporting and Conformance
An email authentication protocol that uses SPF and DKIM to determine the authenticity of an email message.
DNAT: A technique for transparently changing the destination IP address of an incoming packet.
DNS: A hierarchical and decentralized naming system for computers, services, or other resources connected to the Internet or a private network.
DoS: An attack that makes a computer or network resource unavailable to its intended users.
DPO: An individual who oversees an organization's data privacy strategy and implementation.
DRP: A documented process or set of procedures to recover and protect a business IT infrastructure in the event of a disaster.
DSA: A Federal Information Processing Standard for digital signatures.
DSL: A type of broadband internet connection that uses existing copper telephone lines.
EAP: A framework frequently used in wireless networks and Point-to-Point connections.
ECB: A mode of operation for a block cipher, where each block of plaintext is encrypted independently.
ECC: A public key cryptography algorithm based on the mathematics of elliptic curves.
ECDHE: A key exchange protocol based on elliptic curve cryptography that provides perfect forward secrecy.
ECDSA: A digital signature algorithm using elliptic curve cryptography.
EDR: A solution that helps organizations detect, investigate, and mitigate security incidents on endpoint devices.
EFS: A feature of the NTFS file system that allows files to be encrypted.
ERP: A type of software that organizations use to manage their day-to-day activities.
ESN: A unique identifier assigned to a mobile device.
ESP: A protocol within the IPsec suite that provides authentication, integrity, and confidentiality for packets.
FACL: A list of permissions attached to an object that specifies which users or system processes are granted access to that object.
FDE: The encryption of an entire disk or partition.
FIM: A security process for ensuring the integrity of files and data.
FPGA: An integrated circuit designed to be configured by a customer or a designer after manufacturing.
FRR: A measure of the likelihood that a biometric security system will incorrectly reject an access attempt.
FTP: A standard network protocol used to transfer files from one host to another over a TCP-based network.
FTPS: An extension of FTP that adds support for the Transport Layer Security (TLS) and the Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) protocols.
GCM: A mode of operation for symmetric key cryptographic block ciphers that has been widely adopted for authenticated encryption.
GDPR: A regulation in EU law on data protection and privacy.
GPG: A free implementation of the OpenPGP standard for encrypting and decrypting data.
GPO: A collection of settings that define what a system will look like and how it will behave for a defined group of users.
GPU: A specialized electronic circuit designed to accelerate the processing of images.
GRE: A tunneling protocol used to encapsulate a wide variety of network layer protocols into point-to-point connections.
HA: A characteristic of a system that aims to ensure an agreed level of operational performance.
HDD: A non-volatile storage device that stores digitally encoded data on rapidly rotating platters with magnetic surfaces.
HIDS: A security system that monitors and analyzes the internals of a computing system.
HIPS: A security system that monitors and analyzes the internals of a computing system to prevent intrusions.
HMAC: A specific type of message authentication code involving a cryptographic hash function and a secret cryptographic key.
HOTP: An algorithm that computes a one-time password from a shared secret key and the current time.
HSM: A physical computing device that safeguards and manages digital keys for strong authentication.
HTML: The standard markup language for documents designed to be displayed in a web browser.
IaC: Managing and provisioning infrastructure through code
ICMP: Network layer protocol for error messages
IdP: Entity that issues and manages identity information
IDS: Security system for detecting unauthorized access
IEEE: Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers
Professional organization for electrical and electronics standards
IKE: Protocol for key exchange in IPsec
IPS: Security system for preventing unauthorized access
IR: Process of managing and mitigating security incidents
IRP: Document outlining steps in incident response
ISSO: Security professional responsible for information systems
KEK: Key used for encrypting other keys
L2TP: Tunneling protocol for creating virtual private networks
LAN: Network that spans a small geographic area
MaaS: Delivery of monitoring services over the internet
MAC: Authentication tag for ensuring data integrity
MAN: Network that covers a larger geographic area than a LAN
MBR: Data structure on a storage device
MD5: Hash function producing a 128-bit hash value
MDF: Telecommunication frame that interconnects and manages telecommunications wiring
MFP: Printer that can perform multiple functions
MMS: Messaging service for sending multimedia content
MSA: Contract that outlines terms between parties
MTBF: Predicted elapsed time between inherent failures of a system
MTTF: Predicted time until a non-repairable system fails
MTTR: Average time to repair a failed system
MTU: Maximum size of a data packet
NAC: Security solution controlling access to a network
NAT: Technique for modifying network address information
NDA: Legal agreement to protect confidential information
NIDS: Security system for detecting network-based attacks
NIPS: Security system for preventing network-based attacks
OCSP: Protocol for checking the status of a digital certificate
OID: Unique identifier in a naming hierarchy
OS: System software that manages computer hardware
OSINT: Intelligence collected from publicly available sources
OSPF: Routing protocol for internet protocol networks
OT: Technology used to control industrial operations
P12: File format for storing cryptographic keys and certificates
P2P: Network where each computer can act as both a client and a server
PAC: Script used by web browsers to automatically configure proxy settings
PAP: Authentication protocol using a username and password
PAT: Technique for mapping multiple private IP addresses to a single public IP address
PCAP: File format for packet capture data
PCI DSS: Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard
Security standard for handling credit card information
PDU: Device that distributes electric power to computers and networking equipment
PFS: Cryptographic property ensuring that a session key derived from a set of long-term keys cannot be compromised
PHI: Health-related information tied to an individual
PII: Information that can be used to identify an individual
PKI: Infrastructure for managing digital keys and certificates
PUP: Software that may be unwanted by the user
RA: Entity responsible for assigning and managing digital certificates
RACE: Research and Development in Advanced Communications Technologies in Europe
RAS: Server that enables remote access to a network
RAT: Malicious software allowing unauthorized remote access
RFID: Technology for wireless communication of data
RIPEMD: RACE Integrity Primitives Evaluation Message Digest
ROI: Performance measure for evaluating the efficiency of an investment
RPO: Maximum tolerable period for data loss
RTO: Target time for resuming operations after a disaster
RTOS: Operating system designed for real-time applications
RTP: Protocol for delivering audio and video over IP networks
SAML: XML-based open standard for exchanging authentication and authorization data
SCAP: Standard for automating the vulnerability management, measurement, and policy compliance evaluation
SDK: Set of tools for software development
SDLC: Process for planning, creating, testing, and deploying software
SDN: Network architecture where control is decoupled from hardware
SFTP: Ensures secure file transfer over a network
SHA: Generates a fixed-size hash value from input data
SIM: Stores information on a mobile device
SLA: Defines the level of service between parties
SLE: Measures potential financial loss from a security incident
SMS: Allows the exchange of short text messages
SoC: Integrates all components on a single chip
SPIM: Unsolicited spam messages over messaging platforms
SSD: Uses NAND-based flash memory for data storage
SSH: Provides secure remote access to systems
SSL: Ensures secure communication over a network
SSO: Allows users to access multiple systems with one login
SWG: Filters and monitors web traffic for security
TACACS+: Terminal Access Controller Access Control System
TAXII: Trusted Automated eXchange of Indicator Information
Standardizes threat intelligence sharing in cybersecurity
TCP/IP: Defines how data is transmitted over the Internet
TGT: Used in Kerberos authentication for obtaining service tickets
TLS: Ensures secure communication over a computer network
TOC: Security concept checking conditions at a specific time
TOTP: Generates one-time passwords based on time
TOU: Pricing based on the time of day
UEFI: Spec for firmware that replaces BIOS
URL: Specifies the web address of a resource
USB: Standard for connecting devices to a computer
USB OTG: Allows USB devices to act as hosts
UTM: Combines security functions for comprehensive protection
UTP: Type of cable used in networking
VDE: Simulates a desktop environment on a remote server
VLAN: Logical network segment for better traffic control
VLSM: Customizes subnet masks for efficient IP address allocation
VM: Emulates a computer within a computer
VoIP: Transmits voice communications over the Internet
VPC: Cloud computing environment isolated for a specific user
VPN: Secures communication over a public network
VTC: Enables visual communication over a network
WAF: Protects web applications from cyber threats
WAP: Connects wireless devices to a wired network
WIDS: Monitors and analyzes wireless network traffic
WIPS: Prevents unauthorized access to wireless networks
WO: Document requesting work to be done
WPS: Simplifies the process of connecting devices to a Wi-Fi network
XDR: Security approach that goes beyond traditional methods
XOR: Logical operation for combining binary values
XSRF: Type of malicious exploit of a website
